The binding of Holliday structure resolving endonuclease VII to cruciform DNA was studied in the electron microscope. The protein was found to bind either to the junction or to one of the arms or an end of one of the arms of the construct. The amount of bound protein was determined by measuring the size of the complexes. On average, one complex containing three dimers was found per one molecule of cruciform DNA. The binding of Holliday structure resolving endonuclease VII to cruciform DNA was studied in the electron microscope. The protein was found to bind either to the junction or to one of the arms or an end of one of the arms of the construct. The amount of bound protein was determined by measuring the size of the complexes. On average, one complex containing three dimers was found per one molecule of cruciform DNA. endo-VII electrophoretic mobility shift assays electron microscope. Endonuclease VII (endo-VII)1 is the product of gene 49 of phage T4 (T4). It is a versatile endonuclease with a broad substrate profile. Besides resolving four-way and three-way junctions, the nuclease also recognizes mismatches, heteroduplex loops, single strand overhangs, flap substrates, nicks, gaps, bent DNA, bulky adducts (all reviewed in Ref. 1Kemper B. Nickoloff J.A. Hoekstra M. Biochemistry, Genetics and Cell Biology. Humana Press, Totowa, NJ1997: 179-204Google Scholar) and, as recently shown, apyrimidinic sites (AP-sites) (2Greger B. Kemper B. Nucleic Acids Res. 1998; 26: 4432-4438Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). The enzyme introduces staggered nicks flanking the targets within a distance of 2–6 nucleotides. In the case of Holliday structures, this results in precise resolution of the junction and formation of patch and splice recombinants. The enzyme is essential for phage growth in vivo and is responsible for resolving branches in the newly synthesized DNA that otherwise block the translocation of the molecule during DNA packaging (3Flemming M. Deumling B. Kemper B. Virology. 1993; 196: 910-913Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar, 4Kemper B. Brown D.T. J. Virol. 1976; 18: 1000-1015Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 5Frankel F.R. Batcheler M.L. Clark C.F. J. Mol. Biol. 1971; 62: 439-463Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). Endo-VII contains 157 amino acids and has a molecular mass of 18.2 kDa (6Tomaschewski J. Rueger W. Nucleic Acids Res. 1987; 15: 3632-3633Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 7Barth K.A. Powell D. Trupin M. Mosig G. Genetics. 1988; 120: 329-343Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The protein forms dimers in solution that easily exchange subunits among each other (8Kosak H.G. Kemper B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1990; 194: 779-784Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar, 9Giraud-Panis M.J.E. Lilley D.M.J. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 2528-2534Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar, 10Golz S. Christoph A. Birkenkamp-Demtroeder K. Kemper B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 245: 573-580Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Formation of dimers activates the nuclease (11Birkenbihl R.P. Kemper B. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4527-4534Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). Each dimer contains two DNA binding sites composed of one N- and one C-terminal portion of each subunit and two cleavage sites (12Birkenbihl R.P. Kemper B. J. Mol. Biol. 1998; 280: 73-83Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). In theory, one dimer would be sufficient to cleave two strands flanking the junction of a Holliday structure or its substitute, a cruciform DNA. Interestingly, electromobility shift assays (EMSA) indicated that the synthetic cruciform DNA CF01 binds in total three dimers of endo-VII (12Birkenbihl R.P. Kemper B. J. Mol. Biol. 1998; 280: 73-83Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). To further study the DNA binding of endo-VII, we have visualized the DNA-protein complexes formed between a cruciform DNA and the protein in the electron microscope and have calculated the amount of protein bound by visual inspection. Again we find that three dimers of endo-VII bind to the junction of the cruciform DNA. The preparation of samples for the electron microscope was done essentially as described earlier (14Lee S. Cavallo L. Griffith J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 7532-7539Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar). Briefly, a 50-fold molar excess of endo-VII dimer was incubated for 15 min at room temperature with 100 ng of J12 DNA in 50 μl of 10 mm HEPES (pH 7.5) and 100 mm NaCl. After fixation at room temperature for 5 min with 0.8% (v/v) glutaraldehyde, the solution containing protein-DNA complexes was filtered through a 2-ml Bio-Gel A5 m-column (Bio-Rad) to remove excess unbound protein. The samples were then mixed with spermidine buffer giving a final concentration of 0.1 mm spermidine, 0.1 mmMgCl2, 7.5 mm NaCl, and 5 mm KCl and then transferred to carbon foils. After a rotary showcast at 10−7 torr with tungsten, the samples were examined in a Phillips CM12 electron microscope. Proteins endo-VIIWT and cleavage-deficient mutant protein [Asp]-EVII-(1–156) were used for the EM studies. Proteins endo-VIIWT and His-tagged covalently linked endo-VII dimer CD321 were used for EMSA. Expression and purifications of the proteins and removal of the 6xHis tag (where applicable) were performed as described before (10Golz S. Christoph A. Birkenkamp-Demtroeder K. Kemper B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 245: 573-580Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 11Birkenbihl R.P. Kemper B. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4527-4534Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar, 12Birkenbihl R.P. Kemper B. J. Mol. Biol. 1998; 280: 73-83Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar, 13Golz S. Birkenbihl R. Kemper B. DNA Res. 1995; 2: 277-284Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). DNA-binding reactions were performed in 10 μl of binding buffer (50 mm Tris HCl, pH 8.0, 5 mm EDTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol). Varying amounts of protein were incubated with 1 fmol (100 pm final concentration) of radioactively labeled cruciform DNA CF01 at 16 °C. After 15 min, 2.5 μl of loading buffer (40 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 4 mm EDTA, 25% glycerol, 0.05% bromphenol blue, and 400 μg/ml bovine serum albumin) were added to each sample. The mixtures were immediately loaded onto an 8% native PAA gel and run at 4 °C for 2.5 h at 7 V/cm in electrophoresis buffer (6.7 mm Tris HCl pH 8.1, 3.3 mm sodium acetate, and 2 mm EDTA). The DNA was visualized by autoradiography of the dried gels and quantitated by phosphoimaging on a Fuji BAS1000. Endo-VII has a general tendency to bind to single-stranded DNA as well as double-stranded DNA (15Kemper B. Garabett M. Eur. J. Biochem. 1981; 115: 123-131Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar, 16Kemper B. Garabett M. Courage U. Eur. J. Biochem. 1981; 115: 133-141Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). The protein also binds with high affinity to cruciform DNA and mismatch-containing oligonucleotides (10Golz S. Christoph A. Birkenkamp-Demtroeder K. Kemper B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 245: 573-580Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar,11Birkenbihl R.P. Kemper B. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4527-4534Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar, 17Golz S. Birkenkamp-Demtroeder K. Kemper B. Nucleic Acids Res. 1998; 26: 1132-1133Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). When synthetic cruciform DNA CF01 was exposed to increasing amounts of endo-VII, three distinct shift positions were revealed by band shift analyses suggesting one, two, and three units of protein binding in succession to the DNA (Fig. 1 a, lanes 1 through7). The size of the smallest binding unit of endo-VII was determined as a dimer because a synthetic covalently linked endo-VII dimer shifted the DNA to the same positions in the gel as the endo-VII wild-type protein (11Birkenbihl R.P. Kemper B. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4527-4534Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). To further analyze the modalities of endo-VII-binding to cruciform DNA, we loaded the protein on cruciform DNA and inspected the samples after fixation with glutaraldehyde in the electron microscope. The same procedure and the same DNA were recently used successfully to demonstrate the binding of tumor suppressor protein p53 to cruciform DNA (14Lee S. Cavallo L. Griffith J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 7532-7539Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar). Two forms of endo-VII were used in these studies. These were the enzymatically active wild-type protein (pEVIIWT) and the enzymatically inactive mutant protein ([Asp]-EVII-(1–156)) which lacks the ultimate C-terminal amino acid 157 and carries a point mutation in codon 62 (EVII-N62D). This mutant has recently been described (10Golz S. Christoph A. Birkenkamp-Demtroeder K. Kemper B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 245: 573-580Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 18Christoph A. Heesberg G. Kemper B. J. Mol. Biol. 1998; 277: 529-540Crossref PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar). Typical photographs from the analyses are shown in Fig. 2. A list summarizing and classifying all samples investigated is given in Table I. Among 151 inspected intact cruciform DNA molecules (Fig. 2 a), 132 were found associated with distinct protein complexes after the reaction with EVIIWT. The complexes were either located at the junction (43 complexes) (Fig. 2 b), somewhere along the arms (47 complexes) (Fig. 2 c) or at the end of one of the arms (42 complexes) (Fig. 2 d). A similar result was obtained when EVIIWTwas replaced by mutant protein [Asp]-EVII-(1–156). In this experiment, a total of 138 molecules were inspected, and 51 of them had protein complexes bound to the junction, 30 carried complexes somewhere along one of the arms, and 48 had the protein attached to the end of one arm. In both experiments, the majority of DNA-protein complexes contained only one protein complex per DNA. A molar ratio of endo-VII dimers to cruciform DNA molecules of 50:1 was found to give the best results in terms of number and size of protein-DNA complexes. When a 10-fold higher concentration of protein was used, large amorphous aggregates of protein were found along with “regular” sized complexes. The aggregates were considered unspecific and left out of this study. When the mutant protein was used in the presence of 10 mmMgCl2 (which is possible because the mutant protein is enzymatically inactive and does not degrade the substrate), the number of molecules with protein complexes bound to the junction was significantly higher (73 complexes) when compared with those with protein bound along one arm (32 complexes) or at the end of one arm (34 complexes). This suggests that Mg2+ may increase the affinity of endo-VII to the junction. Mg2+-induced changes in the secondary structure of cruciform DNA have recently been reported (19Bhattacharyya A. Murchie A.I.H. von Kitzing E. Diekmann S. Kemper B. Lilley D.M.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 221: 1191-1207Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar). They may eventually make the structure more apt to bind endo-VII protein. How much endo-VII binds to the junction of a cruciform DNA? We approached the problem by measuring the diameters of protein complexes on enlarged photos and compared these numbers to measures of the length of one arm of the cruciform DNA on the same photo. One arm contains 565 base pairs with a predicted length of 1,921 Å. The relative diameter of the protein complex was then calculated to be 171 ± 43 Å as averaged from ten samples. Remarkably, this number was nearly the same as the diameter of p53dimer protein complexes (169 Å) formed under the same experimental conditions using the same cruciform DNA (14Lee S. Cavallo L. Griffith J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 7532-7539Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar). The mass of DNA bound p53dimer complexes was originally estimated from comparisons to the mass of T7 DNA polymerase, used as an internal standard, times the ratio of the projected areas to the 3/2 power (14Lee S. Cavallo L. Griffith J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 7532-7539Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar). The calculated mass of endo-VII complexes was about 108 kDa, 2Mass EVIIcomplex = mass p53 ((diameter EVIIcomplex)/(diameter p53dimers))32 = 106 kDa (171 Å/169 Å)32= 107.8 kDa. suggesting that on the average three dimers of endo-VII bind to cruciform DNA. This is consistent with the results obtained by EMSA (Fig. 1, lanes 1 through 7). However, we want to emphasize that the molar ratio of endo-VII protein to cruciform DNA required to shift the DNA to the third position in the gel was about 50-fold higher here than the ratio used in the EM analyses. We suspect that the binding equilibrium between protein and DNA is shifted under the EM conditions such that the back reaction is prevented, possibly by the fixation with glutaraldehyde. Unfortunately, this hypothesis could not be tested with cruciform DNA CF01 and EMSA using EM cross-linking conditions because the substrate was not stable (results not shown). Interestingly, when the same protein concentration was used for shift experiments with linear double-stranded DNA containing a C/C mismatch, two shift positions were obtained (Fig. 1 a, lanes 8–11). From the band shift experiment shown in Fig. 1 a, a dissociation constant (K d) of 5 nm (5 × 10−9 m) was calculated for endo-VIIWT and cruciform DNA CF01 (Fig. 1 b) and 14 nm (1.4 × 10−8 m) for mismatch containing substrate Bea46MM11(Fig. 1 c). A consistent failure to obtain footprints with endo-VII and any of its substrates including cruciform DNA and mismatch-containing DNA (results not shown) indicate that the affinity of the protein to DNA is too low. Only when extremely high protein to DNA ratios (≫1000-fold molar excess of endo-VII) are chosen is footprinting possible (20Parsons C.A. Kemper B. West S.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 9285-9289Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Resolution of Holliday structures requires a minimum of two staggered nicks placed across the junction, which could in principle be done by one protein dimer. The three-dimensional structure of a cruciform DNA in solution was predicted by model building as an X-shaped scissors like arrangement of the arms in space with a small angle of 60° between two pairs of arms and a compensatory wide angle of 120° between the other two pairs of arms (19Bhattacharyya A. Murchie A.I.H. von Kitzing E. Diekmann S. Kemper B. Lilley D.M.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 221: 1191-1207Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar, 21von Kitzing E. Lilley D.M. Diekmann S. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 2671-2683Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar). Binding of endo-VII to cruciform DNA was reported to cause a structural change from an X-shaped molecule into a planar +-shaped molecule (22Pöhler J.R.G. Giraud-Panis M.J. Lilley D.M. J. Mol. Biol. 1996; 260: 678-696Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). Based on the two-fold symmetry of the cruciform DNA, one can easily envisage how binding of two arms by one endo-VII dimer (comprising two DNA-binding sites) would be sufficient to resolve the structure. By the same structural argument, one can also envisage how a second endo-VII dimer binds to the same DNA molecule without interfering with the first dimer. Binding of three dimers, however, is not understood. We therefore believe that binding of the third dimer is unspecific, possibly reflecting protein-protein interactions viadifferently charged surfaces of the protein. The recently obtained crystal structure of endo-VII revealed that the dimer has two differently charged surfaces indeed. 3D. Suck, personal communication. Dwelling upon this argument further, the two dimers binding to a mismatch oligonucleotide would then reflect one dimer binding specifically to the two arms flanking the mismatch and one dimer adhered nonspecifically to the first. It should be noted, that the amount of endo-VII protein required to shift DNA CF01 to the first, second, and third position in the gel is about 1,000-, 20,000-, and 300,000-fold higher, respectively, than is required for cleavage of 50% of the same DNA in the nuclease reaction. We therefore assume that the three-dimer complexes reflect the special situation caused by high protein concentrations that may or may not be relevant in vivo.
